**Term:** Spring 2022

**Time:** Friday 10:20-12:10

**Location:** Yun 201      

**Instructors this Semester:**  

Justin Prystash: [jsprystash@gmail.com](mailto:jsprystash@gmail.com)

Brena Yu-Chen Tai : [yuchentai@gapps.ntnu.edu.tw](mailto:yuchentai@gapps.ntnu.edu.tw)

**Course Description and Objectives:**

This two-semester seminar is designed to help MA students become better academic writers. We will develop several different skills that are necessary for academic writing at the MA level: (1) interpreting literature, or “primary sources,” through close reading; (2) interpreting academic scholarship or “secondary sources”; (3) conducting research and documenting sources; and (4) bringing together interpretations of primary and secondary sources into a well-organized academic essay. This course takes a team-based approach, with students working together with professors and peers to improve their writing through several different writing-based activities and workshops. In the first semester, students will complete short writing assignments with the ultimate goal of writing a very short academic paper; in the second semester, students will work toward writing (or substantially revising) a complete academic essay and sharing their work in a conference presentation. 

\* This is a one-year seminar for literature-track students in the English department, thus **_the fall semester is a prerequisite._**

**Texts:**

1.  _MLA Handbook for Writers of Research Papers_ (9th Ed) 
2.  Students will read primary and secondary texts in consultation with their instructors.

**Course Policies:**

*   Punctuality in turning in your homework is required. Exceptions are allowed only under emergency circumstances or with notification in advance. 
*   Any student who plagiarizes will fail the course.
*   Students must be registered in the class to attend; auditing is not allowed. 

**Course Requirements:** 

*   Attendance & participation: 20%
*   Two writing assignments: 20% x2 =40% (around 600 words/assignment)
*   Conference presentation: 15%
*   Final paper: 25% (around 2,000 words)
